item.title: Anthropology Museum- Photography Exhibit by James Barker
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: In 1965, WSU staff member James Barker was asked by a group of WSU campus and Pullman community activists to travel from Pullman to Selma, Alab., to take photographs of the famous march led by Martin Luther King Jr. Barker will bring his images to Pullman and talk about his experience. He will be joined by then ASWSU President David Warren. A reception from 4:30-6:00 precedes the panel presentation; the exhibit itself will be displayed until Mar. 20. See a related WSU Magazine article. Common Reading Stamp available at panel event only.

item.title: Outsider Art: Work from New Folsom Prison, 1994-2014
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: The exhibit features art works created at New Folsom Prison between 1994-2014 by incarcerated artists participating in the California Arts in Corrections Program (AIC). None of the artists whose work is displayed had formal art training before joining AIC classes. The English Department offers this exhibit in conjunction with the WSU Common Reading program’s 2015-16 selection of the book Just Mercy, by Bryan Stevenson. Stevenson’s book, and his work as the founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative, resonates with the mission of AIC in that both projects challenge deeply-held stereotypes about incarcerated people. Both projects also press important and timely questions about what it means to be human and what the practice of mass incarceration says about American society. The exhibit is presented by English faculty member Anna Plemons who studies prison writing programs and has taught creative nonfiction at New Folsom since 2009; specific inquiries about the show can by sent to her at aplemons@wsu.edu. The exhibit will be on display in the Bundy Reading Room until March 2016; reservations to view the show can be made by contacting English at 509-335-2581.

item.title: “The Case of the 12-Year-Old Sheriff Killer: Herbert Niccolls and the Washington Justice System”
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: In the very early morning hours of August 5, 1931, just about 30 miles directly south of Pullman, Wash., Asotin County Sheriff John Wormell and his deputies responded to a report of a burglary at an Asotin store. Twelve-year-old Herbert Niccolls Jr. was inside, stealing gum and tobacco, and emptying the cash register. As the sheriff interrupted the burglary and ordered him to come out, the boy drew a loaded revolver and pulled the trigger. Sheriff Wormell died instantly. This exhibit explores aspects of the crime, the trial, Niccolls’s experiences as a juvenile sentenced to life in the Washington State Penitentiary, and his eventual pardon. His case attracted national attention, notably from Father Edward Flanagan of the famous Boys’ Town home in Nebraska. The exhibit features primary source documents about the case from Manuscripts, Archives, and Special Collections, the Washington State Archives, and the Asotin County Museum.  Common Reading Stamp available; see MASC staff for a stamp to prove attendance at the exhibit.

item.title: Tunnel of Oppression
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly

item.title: Justin Torres, a visiting writer
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Justin Torres, a visiting writer, will visit WSU in Pullman. Please check back for more information.

item.title: Just Mercy author Bryan Stevenson, Common Reading Invited Lecture
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Bryan Stevenson, author of the 2015-16 Common Reading book, Just Mercy, will deliver the annual Common Reading Invited Lecture, answer audience questions, and sign copies of his book. Proof of attendance will be provided to students.

item.title: Power and Privilege 101: Marc Robinson and Jenne Schmidt, WSU Office of Diversity Education
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded:
Week of Welcome

Power and Privilege 101: Marc Robinson and Jenne Schmidt, WSU Office of Diversity Education (Workshop sessions related to the Common Reading book, presented by the WSU Office of Diversity Education) This workshop introduces the concepts of power, identity, and privilege using engaging activities and popular culture media. Co-facilitated by Diversity Education’s social justice peer educators, participants will explore their own identities and avenues to get involved in social justice on campus.
A Compass to Explore the Common Reading, Just Mercy: Marc Robinson and Jenne Schmidt, WSU Office of Diversity Education Using this year’s Common Reading book, Just Mercy, by Brian Stevenson, as the foundation, this workshop explores various social issues, including race, social class, inequality, history, and justice, which underpin the text. This interactive workshop uses activities, video clips, and small group discussions; it provides students with tools to engage in Common Reading conversations about these issues.

item.title: Screening of To Kill a Mockingbird
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded: To Kill a Mockingbird (1962, 129 minutes) (Hosted by the Common Reading Program) Monroeville, Ala., is the home town of celebrated author Harper Lee and the basis for the fictional town of Maycomb in her classic novel To Kill a Mockingbird. It is also the location where Walter McMillian was unjustly accused, tried for murder, incarcerated, and sentenced to death for killing a white woman. Bryan Stevenson, the author of Just Mercy, took on the case postconviction to exonerate McMillian, by proving that witnesses had lied on the stand and the prosecution had illegally suppressed exculpatory evidence. McMillian’s conviction was overturned and he was released in March 2003 after spending six years on death row for a crime he did not commit. Stevenson is attributed with saying that while Monroeville proudly celebrates its connection to the novel and film of To Kill a Mockingbird, the town remained blind to contemporary racial bias and injustices in its administration of justice. “We start this year’s series with a screening of this classic film to provide the context and story that this year’s common reading will challenge and extend,” says Karen Weathermon, co-director of the Common Reading. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Leslie McCall on “The Undeserving Rich: American Beliefs About Inequality”
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded: (Hosted by the Thomas S. Foley Institute for Public Policy and Public Service’s Coffee & Politics Series) Leslie McCall, author and Northwestern University professor of sociology and political science, will discuss American views about income inequality, economic beliefs, and what she believes to be the era of rising inquality. In her latest book, The Undeserving Rich: American Beliefs About Inequality, Opportunity, and Redistribution, McCall challenges widespread assumptions and claims that Americans have desired less inequality for decades. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Faith Lutze on “The Evolving American Prison: Executing the Ideals of Justice, Mercy, and Redemption”
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded: (Hosted by the Common Reading Program) Faith Lutze is  a professor in the WSU Dept. of Criminal Justice and Criminology. Prisons in the United States have a long history of adapting to shifting notions of justice, mercy, and redemption. Criminal justice and prison leaders are expected to translate philosophy into reality for both staff and offenders. Historical and contemporary research shows there is often a gap between our intentions (conscience) as a society and the reality of our practices (action). This presentation illustrates both the good and the bad in our use of prisons to achieve criminal justice goals. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Brian Kemp on “From Mendel’s Pea Plants to DNA Fingerprinting: How one 19th century monk’s observations in the garden form the basis for individual identification in the forensic sciences today”
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded: (Hosted by the Common Reading Program) Brian Kemp, associate professor in the WSU Dept. of Anthropology and the School of Biological Sciences, will introduce the audience to DNA and the structure of the human genome. What is DNA and what does it do? How do we study it? These topics will be addressed in the context of the discovery of the principles of inheritance by Gregor Mendel in his pea plant garden in the 1860s. Beyond being of tremendous historical relevance, Mendel’s observations form the basis today for DNA fingerprinting. Among its many uses, DNA analysis now is a central tool in forensic science, both for the trial of new cases and for the retrial of old cases that predate the use of DNA evidence. By the end of the lecture, audience members will have a full understanding how DNA is used to identify individuals. No prior knowledge is needed! Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Arlene Dávila on “El Mall: The Class and Spatial Politics of Shopping Malls in LA”
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded: (Hosted by the Center for Critical Culture, Gender, and Race Studies, and co-sponsors) Dávila is a New York University professor of anthropology and American studies. Her work focuses on the global political economy of Latino/Latin American cultures, with a focus on Puerto Ricans in the United States. Her most recent publications include Culture Works: Space, Value, and Mobility Across the Neoliberal Americas and other books focusing on comparative race/ethnic studies, urban studies, and media and visual studies. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: “Broken on All Sides: Race, Mass Incarceration, and New Visions for Criminal Justice in the U.S.”
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded: (Film showing hosted by the Common Reading Program) This documentary centers around author and law professor Michelle Alexander’s theory, presented in her book The New Jim Crow, that mass incarceration is a new caste system in America that is enacted through the rise of the drug war, “tough on crime” policies, discretion and bias in policing and sentencing, and the legal discrimination of those with criminal records in almost every aspect of citizenship. See http://brokenonallsides.com for more on this film. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Mary Yu, Washington State Chief Supreme Court Justice
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded: (Sponsored by the Pre-Law Resource Center) Washington State Supreme Court Chief Justice Mary Yu is speaking on campus as part of the Cougar Pre-Law Day sponsored by the Pre-Law Resource Center. The day also includes a panel discussion featuring WSU alumni in the legal profession at 2:30, a Law School Admissions panel at 3:45, and a Law School Admissions fair and reception at 4:30, all in CUE 518. For more information, visit http://prelaw.wsu.edu/pre-law-day. Common Reading Stamp available at Chief Justice Yu’s presentation only.

item.title: “Books for Prisoners Programs”
item.dc:creator: seabertson
item.content:encoded: (Exhibit hosted by WSU Libraries; organized by WSU Instructional Librarian Holly Luetkenhaus, This exhibit highlights books-for-prisoners programs–volunteer organizations across the U.S. that collect donations of books and provide them free of charge to people who are incarcerated. Visitors will learn about the history of programs in the U.S., how they operate, and the benefits they offer. It will feature notes from prisoners who have received books through “Books to Prisoners,” the only program operating out of Washington state, located in Seattle.

item.title: Reflections of a Segregated Life- Jeff Guillory
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Jeff Guillory, WSU Director of Diversity Education, will discuss his experiences growing up in the Jim Crow south during the 1950s and 1960s, and the effect this system had on him at each stage of his formative years. It is a personal story that provides the listener with an immersion experience with hate and its far-reaching effects on a young man’s view of himself, authority, race, education, and law enforcement until the sudden shock of his first encounter with integration turns everything upside down. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Reflections of a Segregated Life, Jeff Guillory
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Jeff Guillory, WSU Director of Diversity Education, will discuss his experiences growing up in the Jim Crow south during the 1950s and 1960s, and the effect this system had on him at each stage of his formative years. It is a personal story that provides the listener with an immersion experience with hate and its far-reaching effects on a young man’s view of himself, authority, race, education, and law enforcement until the sudden shock of his first encounter with integration turns everything upside down. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: At Night I Fly, Film Showing
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: “At Night I Fly” is an internationally-acclaimed film about the New Folsom maximum-security prison in California. Its U.S. début was at the 2013 Fortnight Film Festival at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City. The website for the film says “…men at (New Folsom) let us see their world…(which is) less about dangerous drama and more, as one of them describes, about isolation. About closure of both the mind and the heart. And the spirit.” This intimate documentary shows prisoners, most serving a life sentence, who refuse such closure and instead work to uncover and express themselves. Their primary tool is making art and the film takes us to New Folsom’s Arts in Corrections’ room, to prison poetry readings, gospel choirs, blues guitar on the yard, and to many more scenes of creation. The film “shows the artistic and human journey these men take, as well as the need that fuels it, and the beauty and pain encountered along the way.” Following the showing there will be a question-and-answer session with Jim Carlson, California’s Arts in Corrections (AIC) Program former director, who appears in the film. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Business Technology Symposium (hosted by Carson College of Business)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Every year the WSU Carson College of Business hosts a panel of technology executives from leading businesses to discuss how emerging technologies are transforming business practices—both in creating new opportunities and new challenges.  The 2018 panelists are Kashif Ansari (Vice President, Dell EMC), Megan Bigelow (Portland Women in Tech), Frank Harrill (Director of Security, Schweitzer Engineering), and Cameron Schwarz (Systems Engineering Manager, Dell EMC). For more on these speakers and the symposium, see https://business.wsu.edu/news-events/events/business-technology-symposium/ . Verification of attendance for the Common Reading available.

item.title: Poem Reading and Q&A with Visiting Writer Jericho Brown
item.dc:creator: madeline.neigel
item.content:encoded:
Jericho Brown is one of the most brilliant young stars of American poetry today. Not only does his work cite America’s history with slavery, one of the largest forced migrations in human history, it also explores complacency—the inaction of people who choose not to leave their zones of safety to understand larger problems of social justice. Brown is the recipient of a Whiting Writers’ Award, and fellowships from the John Simon Guggenheim Foundation, the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University, and the National Endowment for the Arts, as well as numerous other awards and honors. He is an associate professor and the director of the Creative Writing Program at Emory University. Brown’s reading and Q&A will challenge students to think about fear, emergency, and survival in present-day America and around the world. Sponsored by the English Department’s Visiting Writers Series.

Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Jasiri X, keynote speaker for the WSU MLK Community Celebration
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Jasiri X is the award-winning hip-hop artist, emcee, blogger, and community activist from Pittsburgh, Penn., who uses his music to provide a social commentary on a variety of issues. He co-founded the anti-violence groupOne Hood, and started the 1Hood Media Academy to teach African-American boys how to analyze and create media for themselves.Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Global Case Final Competition
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: (Hosted by International Programs) Time and place TBD.

item.title: Jay Smooth- New York based hip-hop scholar and cultural commentator
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly

item.title: Carol Hinds on "Re-Imagining Rehabilitation: A Mother's Story"
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Carol Hinds is the parent of an inmate at California State Prison-Sacramento (New Folsom Prison) and has served as secretary on the prison’s Inmate Family Council for the past 14 years. Her son is serving a 25-to-life sentence through 2025. In addition to her work with the Council effecting policy change and supporting inmate families, she has spoken before the California legislature and at national conferences, sharing her personal story about the positive and healing effects that art, music, and creative writing have had on her son and others in the prison. Hinds has become a strong advocate for prison arts programs and her story challenges audiences to think broadly about what an agenda for restorative justice might look like. She is cited in Paths of Discovery: Arts Practice and Its Impact in California Prison (Brewster 2012). Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Sister Simone Campbell, Foley Institute Speaker
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Sister Simone Campbell is the executive director of NETWORK, a national Catholic social justice lobby. She is a religious leader, attorney, and poet with extensive experience in public policy and advocacy for systemic change. She authored A Nun on the Bus: How All of Us Can Create Hope, Change, and Community. In Washington, D.C., she lobbies on issues of peace-building, immigration reform, healthcare, and economic justices. She is a noted national speaker and educator on public policy issues and has led three cross-country “Nuns on the Bus” trips, focused on social justice issues. She is a member of the Sisters of Social Service religious community and has served as its leader in the U.S., Mexico, Taiwan, and the Philippines. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Terry Tempest Williams
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Terry Tempest Williams is called “the citizen writer” who speaks and speaks out on behalf of an ethical stance toward life. A naturalist and fierce advocate for freedom of speech, she has consistently shown us how environmental issues are social issues that ultimately become matters of justice. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Bringing Justice to Life
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: This is an interactive event intended to inform and educate the WSU community about a variety of social justice issues. Students enrolled in HD 205 (Developing Effective Communication and Life Skills) have been charged with using their creativity to engage others in better understanding a social justice issue about which they are passionate.  The drop-in event is intended to celebrate creativity and engagement and to honor justice. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Faith Lutz leads discussion of "College Behind Bars: Why Educate Inmates?"
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Prison education programs have been shown to have positive outcomes. When education programs are implemented in prisons, inmates are significantly less likely to become repeat offenders and are more likely to find stable employment after release. Despite these benefits, the number of education programs available in US prisons has dropped from 350 postsecondary programs in 1990 to only 12 by 2005. Why aren’t we prioritizing education in prisons when the research shows that it reduces repeat crime? What can be done to change this? Dept. of Criminal Justice and Criminology Professor Faith Lutze will lead the discussion with students, faculty, staff, and community members. Students can register for this event on CougSync, and Global Campus and urban campus students are invited to join the discussion via live stream on CCE’s YouTube channel. Visit cce.wsu.edu for more information. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: "La Causa" by Living Voices
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: In the late 1960s, a new movement changed the lives of Latin American farm workers who fought for civil rights and decent working conditions. Living Voices brings this chapter of American history and the movement for greater justice to live by presenting one woman’s struggle to free her family and people from poverty. Free for WSU Students.  Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: James Meredith presents "The fight for equality then and now"
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: The Foley Institute is pleased to present civil rights icon James Meredith, who will discuss his personal experiences fighting for equal rights and his view of the struggle today. Meredith was the first black student to integrate the University of Mississippi in 1962.  In 1966, he was shot while leading the Mississippi March Against Fear.  He has spent the decades since fighting for equality, speaking, and writing about his experiences, Mississippi and American history. Common Reading Stamp available.  (Sponsored by the Foley Institute with support from the WSU President’s Office, Associated Students of Washington State University, and the School of Politics, Philosophy, and Public Affairs)

item.title: Gary Jenkins and Bill Gardner on "The Current Evolution of Law Enforcement"
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Pullman Chief of Police Gary Jenkins and WSU Chief of Police Bill Gardner will discuss how law enforcement continuously evolves to meet societal needs and demands. Following a short history, the police leaders will talk about current events that have made international news and the role of technology, training, and philosophy in law enforcement. Common Reading Stamp available.

item.title: Matt Stichter (Philosophy) on the Ethics of Punishment
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly

item.title: John Roll (Nursing) on Health Issues and Incarceration
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly

item.title: Kevin Willmott- Visiting Writer
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly

item.title: Nancy Rodriguez, Director, National Institute of Justice on "Crime and Race"
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly

item.title: Paula Young Shelton workshop on "Teaching Social Justice in the Elementary Classroom"
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Paula Young Shelton, the daughter of Civil Rights activist Andrew Young, is an early childhood educator and the author of the children’s book Child of the Civil Rights Movement. This award-winning book presents a child’s view of participating in the Civil Rights Movement, including the historic march from Selma to Montgomery.  Ms. Shelton commitment to enriching the lives of young children has taken her to diverse teaching positions in East Africa, the public housing projects of Atlanta, elite neighborhoods in New York City, and the culturally diverse communities of Washington, DC.

item.title: Screening of the movie Selma
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: This screening is being hosted by the MLK Committee as part of this year’s MLK observance, “Selma to Pullman: Honoring the Past, Creating the Future.” This film chronicles the 1965 march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama, to secure equal voting rights.

item.title: James Barker and David Warren on the 1965 Selma March
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: In 1965, WSU staff member James Barker was asked by a group of WSU campus and Pullman community activists to travel from Pullman to Selma to take photographs of the famous march led by Martin Luther King. Barker and then ASWSU President David Warren, who also traveled to Selma, will speak about their experiences. Hosted by the MLK Committee, a reception will follow at 7 pm. The exhibit itself will on display at the Anthropology Museum in College Hall until March 20.

item.title: Anna Plemons (English) on “Changing the Narrative: Prison Writing in the Age of Mass Incarceration”
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Anna Plemons, who for many years has taught writing to inmates in California’s New Folsom Prison, takes up Bryan Stevenson’s call to “change the narratives that sustain inequality and injustice.” This talk is hosted by the English Department as part of its regular colloquium series.

item.title: “Not All Video Games and the Brat Pack: AIDS Stigma from the 1980s to the Digital Age”
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: By Matt Jeffries (Director, Gender Identity/Expression and Sexual Orientation Resource Center).  While Cline portrays a rosy image of the 1980s, for many communities, the 1980s were rife with strife. In this engaging lecture, the presenter discusses the 1980s and how the LGBT community handled the HIV/AIDS crisis. Additionally, he addresses how stigmas around HIV/AIDS prevail through present day, including in digital spaces. Verification of attendance will be provided.

item.title: Ready Player One author/screenwriter Ernest Cline
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Cline kicks off the 2017-18 year's lineup of faculty-and guest-expert lectures by presenting this year's Common Reading Invited Lecture.  A Q&A and book signing will follow.  Verification of attendance will be provided.

item.title: Visiting Writer Stephen Blackmore
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Sci-fi writer Stephen Blackmore is the author of the Eric Carter noir urban fantasy series, which includes Dead Things, Broken Souls, Hungry Ghosts, and the forthcoming Fire Season.  He has also written for the Gods & Monsters series, the role-playing game Spirit of the Century, the video-game Wasteland 2, and the television series Heroes: Reborn.  His short stories can be found online and in the anthologies Deadly Treats, Uncage Me, Urban Allies, and The Death of All Things. He co-hosts the bi-monthly Los Angeles crime fiction ready series Noir at the Bar L.A.  This reading is sponsored by the Visiting Writers Series in the Dept. of English.  Verification of attendance will be provided.

item.title: “The Future Has Always Been Female: Mary Shelley, Ada Lovelace, and the Origins of Science Fiction and Computing”
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Presented by Roger Whitman (Dept. of English).  Ready Player One depicts a virtual world filled with 80s references, geek culture, and science fiction tropes. But did you know that both science fiction and computing began in the nineteenth century? This talk looks at two female pioneers of the future: Mary Shelley and Ada Lovelace. Shelley was the author of Frankenstein, depicting the creation of life by a human being; and The Last Man, featuring the destruction of all life on Earth by an unnamed plague. Lovelace, on the other hand, wrote the first computer program. Daughter of the “mad, bad, and dangerous to know” Romantic poet Lord Byron, Lovelace became the “countess of numbers” and worked with Charles Babbage on the designs for the analytical engine: the first general purpose computing machine. In the wake of recent struggles in science fiction and video games to recognize the contributions of women, it is important to remember that the future has always been female. Verification of attendance will be provided.

item.title: "Artificial Intelligence"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Presented by Matt Taylor (School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science).  As technology develops, how will artificial intelligence (AI) impact our lives? Taylor, the Allred Distinguished Professor in Artificial Intelligence, will explore the potential benefits and dangers of AI over the next 10 years. He will examine how AI will change our lives both in the physical world and the new space of virtual reality (VR). Read about Taylor's work at http://casas.wsu.edu/2013/06/21/faculty-feature and on his departmental webpage at http://eecs.wsu.edu/~taylorm/. Verification of attendance at his Common Reading presentation is available.

item.title: "Virtual Design and Construction: AR, VR and Virtual Worlds in the Building Industry"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented by Anne Anderson (Construction Management).

People collaborate every day in video games like World of Warcraft, Eve Online, and Halo, where players join forces to battle an enemy. With the use of emerging technologies on the rise in the architecture, engineering and construction (AEC) industry, and as more gamers enter the workforce, the industry appears poised to embrace collaboration using AR, VR and Virtual Worlds. How will working with these technologies change the way we design and build?

item.title: "Am I Addicted to My Phone?" : Healthy Ways to Use Technology Without Getting Hooked
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Presented by Loren Brown (Counseling and Psychological Services). Interactive technology is a useful and integrated part of modern life, yet a growing number of people say it’s causing them problems. As a society we are spending more and more time looking at screens, whether it’s social media or video games, on smart phones or tablets, or even measuring steps, heart rate, and sleep using a fitness tracker. Some people describe their use of these technologies as excessive, obsessive, or even call it an addiction. In this presentation, Brown, a psychologist, will describe why we get hooked, the warning signs of an addiction, and healthy ways of using technology for connection, self-expression, and recreation.

item.title: “Augmented and Virtual Reality as Immersive Learning Tools”
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented by Don McMahon (Teaching and Learning).

Don McMahon, the director of WSU’s Assistive Technology Lab, will present on ways that augmented and virtual reality are currently being used as immersive learning tools in education and also the ways in which these technologies will shape the next ten years of education. McMahon is a leading voice for AR technology serving practical, educational purposes, beyond its more obvious use in gaming. Come and hear McMahon’s predictions of how closely your children’s school experience might resemble that of Wade Watts! Verification of attendance provided.

item.title: "Global Case Competition"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Each year multidisciplinary student groups compete to present solutions to a global problem related that year’s common reading book. Come hear the top teams present their ideas and find out who will be representing WSU on a global study opportunity. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: "Cybersecurity and Privacy in 2017 and Beyond"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented by Adam Hahn (School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science).

This talk will cover the current state of cybersecurity and privacy, exploring our use and dependency on technologies as well as many of the challenges this introduces. Hahn will specifically highlight security threats, vulnerabilities, and their societal impacts. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: "A Literature to Life Stage Presentation of Ray Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Adapted verbatim from the class dystopian novel, this solo performance presents a frightening vision of a world awash in information but rejecting critical thought. In this future society, firemen don’t put out fires; they start them in order to burn books. Returning from work one night, fireman Guy Montag meets his new neighbor, a teenage girl whose free-thinking ideals and liberating spirit cause him to question his life and his own perceived happiness. Presented by WSU Performing Arts, this event is free to all WSU students with ID.  Verification of attendance available.

item.title: "Transboundary Watersheds and the Future Depicted in Ready Player One, a project of Environmental Science 101"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Students in Environmental Science 101 have spent the semester researching the ecosystems of trans-boundary watersheds, places where the major source of water is shared by at least two different communities.  Students’ research projects will culminate in a poster or media presentation in which students will share how the issues facing their watershed relate to the future portrayed by Ready Player One.  Come see the future of our planet through the eyes of WSU students!  Verification of attendance available.

item.title: "Collegiate Leadership Conference", Keynote Address by Rudy Francisco
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Presented by Rudy Francisco, spoken-word poet.

item.title: "Recycling of Electronics and the Need to Find a Long-Term Solution"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Presented by Jason Sampson (Environmental Health and Safety).  Researchers continually strive to improve technology.  In turn, companies provide these improvements as fast as they can be effectively manufactured and marketed.  Consumers purchase electronics to remain on the cutting edge and be competitive in the business world.  It is estimated that annually over 400 billion electronic devices worldwide are determined useless or obsolete and thrown away or recycled.  How does society stay ahead of this growing need for proper disposal of electronic waste?

item.title: "Out on Greek Row:" A Moderated Student Panel
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: This presentation is hosted by the Gender Identity/Expression and Sexual Orientation Resource Center (GIESORC) and the Center for Fraternity and Sorority Life (CFSL).  In Ready Player One the central characters—Wade, Art3mis, and Aech-- introduce various issues of how, why, and to whom we reveal aspects of our identity, especially when we fear resistance or unequal treatment as a result of those identities.  This panel presentation explores this theme and addresses the experiences of LGBTQ students who are members of WSU’s Greek community. Verification of attendance will be provided. (Grey Key event)

item.title: Cyber Security Awareness Summit
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded:
This event, sponsored by WSU Information Technology Services, will feature several speakers addressing issues of cybersecurity in our increasingly online world.  What are the threats? And what is being done to protect our personal, corporate, and government information? Agnes Kirk, the chief information security officer for the State of Washington and advisor for the Department of Homeland Security, will be the keynote speaker at 9 am. Other speakers from industry will follow:

10 am: Terry Boedeker (FireEye) on cyberwar

11 am: Ryan Witt (Proofpoint) on the human factor is online scams

1 pm: Bruce Hembree (Palo Alto) on law enforcement and malware

2 pm: Ken Westin (Splunk) on theft protection and law enforcement tools

3 pm: Adam Hahn (WSU EECS)

For more on these speakers, see https://its.wsu.edu/cyber-awareness/  Verification of attendance will be available for students at each of these speakers throughout the day.

item.title: Rooms of Resistance
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: This annual interactive event (formerly Tunnel of Oppression) encourages participants to learn new perspectives different from their own.  This year’s Rooms of Resistance will use an interactive-museum format; participants will be placed in small groups for presentations and activities that focus on social identities, allyship, and relevant resources. Attendees should expect their visit to last about 1 hour; the last group each evening will begin at 8 pm.  Co-sponsors for the event are the Office of Multicultural Services, Alternatives to Violence of the Palouse, and the Gender Identity/Expression and Sexual Orientation Resource Center.  Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Playing the College Game
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded:
Presented by Jake Leachman (Mechanical Engineering) 

We've all said or heard the statement, "I know, just play the game." But why? We seem stuck in a tragic battle pitting our own personal values against the gamified metrics deemed by our society as important. As a former NCAA football player who suffered a career ending injury, Jake Leachman experienced the thrills, shills, and even pills of playing the game. Now as a professor in mechanical engineering, Leachman coaches student teams to compete successfully in an increasing number of technology innovation competitions. So he asks the question: are metrics and games the future of the Collegiate experience? Or is this a never-ending arms race? As we endeavor to play the game, to be the top student and the top public research university, will we end up winning like in Ready Player One? Verification of attendance available.

item.title: The Privilege to Play: Video Games, Campus Culture, and Identity
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded:
Presented by David Leonard.

This talk will examine how both video games and universities sell “experiences” that not only privilege and empower certain identities and experience but also sell a world that erases, obscures, and finds pleasure in an imagined Other. Both games and college create worlds of tourism, selling not simply an experience of fun and excitement but one in which joy and pleasure are derived through particular understandings of race, gender, sexuality. Highlighting the ways that video games and America’s historically white colleges and universities create experiences that center the needs and pleasure of white male gamers/students, this talk focuses on how these experiences feed off dominant racial and gendered stereotypes. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Screening of "An Inconvenient Sequel" and recorded Q&A with Al Gore
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: The global energy crisis of 2044 provides the background for Ready Player One and is a primary reason that the book’s characters have retreated to the Oasis.  This 2017 film, a follow-up to the 2006 documentary An Inconvenient Truth, explores the current climate situation as well as the emerging energy revolution that could prevent the environmental future Ready Player One predicts. The documentary follows former Vice President Al Gore as he travels the world to promote the goal of overcoming climate change with human ingenuity and passion. The film is 98 minutes long with recorded Q&A with Gore and local discussion to follow. Sponsored by the ASWSU Environmental Sustainability Alliance and the Student Entertainment Board. Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: Innovative Change Film Festival, a presentation and contest of projects from HD 205
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: In Ready Player One, instead of attempting to address the many global issues and crises that face the world in the year 2044, society has turned to the virtual world of innovation.  This semester, HD 205 students were tasked with the challenge of creating innovative solutions to address challenging issues, using videos to promote their ideas. Come see the films and innovative solutions fellow students have created—and vote to award the top presentations. Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: MLK Community Celebration/Speaker Shaun King
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: This year’s MLK Community Celebration focuses on the theme of the Next Generation of Social Justice. Keynote speaker Shaun King is one of many voices—though an increasingly prominent voice—within the movement for Black Lives. By using social media to highlight, amplify, and discuss news of police brutality, racial discrimination, and other civil rights issues, King has become an indispensable source for extending conversations about social justice and equality.  This celebration also includes the presentation of the 2018 MLK Distinguished Service Awards to campus and community winners. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Do We Manage Technology, or Does Technology Manage Us?
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Presented by Deborah Compeau (Management Information Systems/Business Administration). She will explore the many ways in which we both manage and are managed by technologies. From social technologies that draw us in, to artificial intelligence technologies which replace human decision-making, we are confronted by a world where technologies increasingly challenge our agency.  Yet at the same time, these technologies are the products of human design and so human agency remains central to their construction and application. The implications of this duality of influence for individuals and for leaders in organizations will be discussed. Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: Order of the Crimson Key (game): Final Day
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Friday, March 9, is the final day to earn points in the common-reading game, the Order of the Crimson Key. The game was available in fall and into this spring semester. It was created by faculty and staff to align with both this year's Common Reading book, Ready Player One, as well as the program goal to increase students' engagement with and knowledge of the Pullman campus. Everyone who earned at least 9 points in fall and spring is eligible for a raffle of multiple prizes.

item.title: Order of the Crimson Key (game): Points Deadline for Scholarship Eligibility
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Friday,Feb. 9, is the final day to be eligible for a scholarship for participants playing the common-reading game, the Order of the Crimson Key. Players with 9 or more points today are eligible. The game was started in fall and runs until March 9 of  this spring semester. It was created by faculty and staff to align with both this year's Common Reading book, Ready Player One, as well as the program goal to increase students' engagement with and knowledge of the Pullman campus. Everyone who earned at least 9 points in fall and spring is eligible for a raffle of multiple prizes.

item.title: Leveling Up with Undergraduate Research
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Shelley Pressley, director of the Office of Undergraduate Research, will talk about how doing undergraduate research with a mentor (such as a faculty member) can transform students’ time and academic experience at WSU. Joining her will be students already engaged in mentored research whose work connects to topics raised in Ready Player One. Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: Consequences of Using Emerging Technology: Case Studies from Political and Health Communication
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Porismita Borah, associate professor of Communications, will share her research on social media. Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: So, What’s Your Fandom?: Participatory Culture in the Digital Age
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Presented by Lorena O'English, from WSU Libraries. After reading Ready Player One, it’s very clear that author and screenwriter Ernest Cline is a fan of 1980s video games, music, and popular culture. But what does it mean to be a fan? Some of his early screenplays were, in fact, fan fiction. O'English will talk about aspects of fan culture and fanfiction, from their beginnings to the present. Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: Screening of the film "An Inconvenient Sequel"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: TENTATIVE   The global energy crisis of 2044 provides the background for this year's Common Reading book, Ready Player One, and is a primary reason that the book’s characters have retreated to the Oasis. This 2017 film, a follow-up to the 2006 documentary An Inconvenient Truth, explores the current climate situation as well as the emerging energy revolution that could prevent the environmental future that Ready Player One predicts. The documentary follows former U.S. Vice President Al Gore as he travels the world to promote the goal of overcoming climate change with human ingenuity and passion. The film is 98-minutes long and is sponsored by the ASWSU Environmental Sustainability Alliance. Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: Kimberly A. Houser on the legal consequences of VR and AI
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Kimberly A. Houser, a technology attorney and WSU business law professor, will present “Legal Issues with Virtual Reality and Artificial Intelligence” at 4:00 p.m. Mon., Feb. 26, in CUE 202, as part of WSU’s Common Reading Program. The lecture is free and open to the public.

Houser researches and presents on the legal aspects of new technologies and privacy law. She made national headlines in fall of 2017 for her study examining ways that the IRS is breaking privacy laws by mining data from social media and public data pools. In this presentation Houser will talk about how the fast-paced developments in the largely unregulated fields of VR and AI lead to gaps in the law.

Virtual reality is a computerized scenario that gives the feeling of being real, while artificial intelligence simulates human intelligence through machines, primarily computer systems. Among the questions Houser raises are the legal ramifications of replacing human decision-making with machines.

Houser participated at Sci Foo 2018, which is an annual scientific conference organized by Google, Inc., She will also present at South by Southwest Music Festival (SXSW) in Austin, Texas in March on her artificial intelligence and privacy law research. Houser’s publications include the book “Legal Guide to Social Media.” . Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: Data Pitfalls in a Digital World: Protect Yourself
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Rob Crossler, assistant professor of Management Information Systems, will present data pitfalls that are emerging as a result of the increased digitization of society. He will also discuss steps individuals can take to protect themselves. At the conclusion he will provide insight into various career opportunities across a variety of disciplines that are emerging to address these data challenges. Verification of attendance available. (Grey Key event)

item.title: Being Human Virtually
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: David Shier, associate dean of the Honors College and researcher in philosophy of language, early analytic philosophy, and philosophy of sports, will deliver this lecture. The gravitational pull of digital/virtual worlds is undeniable; they grab our attention and pull us right in. We can expect to live increasingly significant parts of our lives in these high-powered, immersive environments. We are by now accustomed to thinking about the enormous impact on the ways we organize our daily lives, our commerce, our communications, and our societies. But we also need to ask ourselves about how these technologies may be transforming us as people, profoundly changing the way we experience the world, our sense of self, and even our concept of what it is to be human.  This lecture will consider just a few of the ways in which life on the digital/virtual frontier is transforming the human experience—from electronic communication, to our ideas of agency, and ultimately to ways we are literally becoming cyborgs. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Storytelling in 3D Spaces
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Brett Atwood, clinical associate professor in Communications and Integrated Strategic Communication Director at WSU's North Puget Sound at Everett, will host a panel discussion about storytelling in virtual reality--using VR technology itself. Much as Wade participates in classes via the Oasis, Dr. Atwood and his panel will be joining students on the Pullman campus and Global Campus via Virtual Reality. Discussing the possibilities and challenges of storytelling in 3D spaces will be Torley Wong, a senior producer at Linden Lab (maker of Sansar and Second Life) from California, and Benhard Drax, an ethnographer who studies people in Second Life participating from Munich, Germany. Come to not only hear about but also experience life in virtual reality. This event is sponsored by the Murrow College of Communication as part of its annual Murrow Symposium.  Verification of attendance available.

item.title: "80s Game Night and Crimson Key Gala"
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: This is the official closing celebration for the two-semester-long Order of the Crimson Key game!  Students who have earned 9 points playing the game by March 9 are eligible for a raffle to win fun prizes. An Oculus Rift VR set will  be available for students to try out. And, players who were notified they'd been drawn to receive tickets to the March 28 premier local showing of the film Ready Player One will pick up their tickets at the gala.

item.title: VR innovators Jay and Uma Jayaram deliver VCEA Lanning Invited Lecture on the Business and Future of Virtual Reality Apr. 5
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Jay and Uma Jayaram, former WSU professors, will return to campus to present the Lanning Lecture for the Voiland College of Engineering and Architecture, discussing the extension of their research into VR technologies to form their company VOKE VR, which they sold to Intel in November 2016. This company, now known as True VR, immerses viewers at live events such as football games, fashion shows, and concerts, and was the first of its kind to deploy panoramic cameras to allow people to view live panoramic video without distortion. VOKE VR first debuted in 2012 at a WSU football game in Martin Stadium, and you likely experienced their technology at the Winter Olympics broadcast from South Korea. The Jayarams will discuss the development of this technology as well as new developments in the business of VR. A reception will following their presentation in Goertzen. For more on their work, see https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/virtual-reality/true-vr-technology-overview.html  Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Student Presentations on Transboundary Watersheds and the Future Depicted in "Ready Player One," a project of Environmental Science 101
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Students in Environmental Science 101 have spent the semester researching the ecosystems of transboundary watersheds, places where the major source of water is shared by at least two different communities. Students' research projects will culminate in a poster or media presentation in which students will share how the issues facing their watershed relate to the future portrayed by Ready Player One. Come see the future of our planet through the eyes of WSU students! Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Innovative Change Film Festival, a presentation and contest of projects from HD 205
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: In Ready Player One, instead of attempting to address the many global issues and crises that face the world in the year 2044, society has turned to the virtual world of innovation. This semester, HD 205 students were tasked with the challenge of creating innovative solutions to address challenging issues, using videos to promote their ideas. Come see films and innovative solutions fellow students have created-- and vote to award the top presentations. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Multiplayer: Critical Perspectives on Video Games and Online Environments (open game play 5-6 p.m., preceding keynote speaker Matt Swanson)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Game producer and project manager Matt Swanson will present the keynote address for the CDSC Spring Symposium. Swanson brings more than 15 years of project management, marketing, and design experience to his role as cxecutive producer at E-Line Media. With a passion for creating games, supporting creative teams, developing inspirational products, and a drive for excellence, Matt oversees all aspects of production in E-Line’s Seattle studio. Most recently he guided production through the successful multi-platform worldwide launch of the award-winning Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna). Swanson’s talk will be preceded by open gameplay of Never Alone from 5-6 pm in Spark 10. Verification of attendance available.  (Grey Key event)

item.title: Issues of Net Neutrality (a panel discussion)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Hosted by ASWSU's Issues and Forums Committee, faculty panelists include Aaron Crandall (Computer Science), Kimberly Houser (Business Law), and Patricia Glazebrook (Philosophy). They will speak about the issue of net neutrality and equal access to online content from the perspective of their own academic field. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Free Speech and Inclusion on Campus
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Howard Gillman, a leading constitutional scholar and the chancellor of the University of California-Irvine, will talk about recent questions regarding free speech on college campuses--including uses of cyber speech.  Recent events involving controversial speakers and groups have raised concerns about how university communities can protect speech while also ensuring an environment of educational equality, free from hate and harassment.  This lecture is sponsored by the Thomas S. Foley Institute for Public Policy and Public Service. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Chasing Coral (film showing) *NEW TIME*
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Following the threat of environmental issues that underlie Ready Player One, the ASWSU Environmental Sustainability Alliance is presenting Chasing Coral, a 2017 documentary film that examines how coral reefs are vanishing at an unprecedented rate around the globe. The film follows a team a divers, photographers, and scientists who set out to document and better understand this underwater mystery. One of the filmmakers will be speaking on campus in April for Earth Week. Verification of attendance available.  *NOTE: This evening's showing time is 8:30 p.m., a change from the originally posted time.

item.title: Silent Sky (performance)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
When Henrietta Leavitt (played by Avery Barnwell) begins work at the Harvard Observatory at the turn of the 20th Century, she isn’t allowed to touch a telescope or express and original idea. Instead, she joins a group of women “computers,” charting the stars for a renowned astronomer who calculates projects in “girl hours” and has no time for the women’s probing theories. Based on the true story of astronomer Henrietta Leavitt, Silent Sky explores a woman’s place in a society during a time of immense scientific discoveries. Social progress, like scientific progress, can be hard to see when one is trapped among earthly complications. Henrietta Leavitt and her female peers believe in both, and their dedication would change the way we understand the heavens and Earth. Verification of attendance available.

Only the March 31 performance at 2 p.m. is FREE for WSU students; all other performances require purchase of $8 student tickets. For more information on this WSU production directed by Mary Trotter, see  https://performingarts.wsu.edu/performances/2018spring/silent-sky.html

item.title: Silent Sky (performance)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
When Henrietta Leavitt (played by Avery Barnwell) begins work at the Harvard Observatory at the turn of the 20th Century, she isn’t allowed to touch a telescope or express and original idea. Instead, she joins a group of women “computers,” charting the stars for a renowned astronomer who calculates projects in “girl hours” and has no time for the women’s probing theories. Based on the true story of astronomer Henrietta Leavitt, Silent Sky explores a woman’s place in a society during a time of immense scientific discoveries. Social progress, like scientific progress, can be hard to see when one is trapped among earthly complications. Henrietta Leavitt and her female peers believe in both, and their dedication would change the way we understand the heavens and Earth. Verification of attendance available.

Only the March 31 performance at 2 p.m. is FREE for WSU students; all other performances require purchase of $8 student tickets. For more information on this WSU production directed by Mary Trotter, see  https://performingarts.wsu.edu/performances/2018spring/silent-sky.html

item.title: Encore Screening of Chasing Coral (Documentary Film)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Following the thread of environmental issues that underlie Ready Player One, the ASWSU Environmental Sustainability Alliance is presenting a second screening of Chasing Coral, a 2017 documentary that examines how coral reefs are vanishing at an unprecedented rate around the globe due to rising ocean temperatures.  The film follows a team of divers, photographers, and scientists who set out to document and better understand how climate change is radically altering the environment just below the ocean's surface. Zack Rago, a young evolutionary biologist and self-professed “coral nerd” who is a featured in the film, will be speaking on campus on April 18 for Earth Week. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Earth Week: Evolutionary biologist Zack Rago (featured in Chasing Coral film) delivers keynote talk
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Zack Rago, a young evolutionary biologist and self-professed “coral nerd” who is featured in the documentary Chasing Coral, will give the keynote talk for Earth Week. Rago’s work with the documentary filmmakers forms the central heart of the 2017 film as audiences experience the devastation to ocean environments through his eyes. For his work in that film Rago was recently honored as a Sea Hero by Scuba Diving magazine. He has also recently helped to document an entirely new species of coral. Rago’s talk is sponsored by the ASWSU Environmental Sustainability Alliance, which will host a reception following the talk. Rago will also hold a press conference with students in Murrow 242 from 4-5 pm. Verification of attendance available for the talk.

item.title: “U.S. Nuclear Weapons: What Are They Good For?”
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Gen. Kevin Chilton, a former astronaut and commander of U.S. Strategic Command, will talk about the question of whether nuclear deterrence has been successful in guaranteeing peace, as well as future U.S. challenges. Chilton retired in 2011 as a four-star general commanding U.S. Strategic Command, where he was responsible for the global command and control of U.S strategic forces. His distinguished career also included flying three space shuttle missions as both commander and pilot, logging over 704 hours in space.  He also served as Deputy Program Manager for the International Space Station. His four-star rank is the highest rank every achieved by an astronaut. This talk is sponsored by the Thomas S. Foley Institute for Public Policy and Public Service. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: The Law and Emerging Technologies
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded:
Gonzaga Law School Dean, Jacob Rooksby, is a renowned expert in intellectual property law and higher education law and policy. He will speak about the legal challenges created by emerging technologies. Rooksby's scholarship has been featured in journals such as The Harvard Journal of Law and Technology, and The Review of Higher Education. He is the author of The Branding of the American Mind: How Universities Capture, Manage, and Monetize Intellectual Property and Why It Matters. Rooksby's talk is co-sponsored by the WSU Pre-Law Resource Center.

Verification of attendance will be provided.

item.title: "The Naked Truth About Life in College" (lecture by Harlan Cohen)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Harlan Cohen, the author of the bestselling book The Naked Roommate: And 107 Other Issues You Might Run Into in College, will present a humorous, interactive session on how to get the most of your WSU experience. Cohen is a nationally syndicated advice columnist whose has spoken at more than 400 college campuses. An expert on life transitions, Cohen offers advice about how to get over the fear of being imperfect so that you can achieve your own soonish goals in college. A reception with pizza will follow the talk in the CUE atrium. This event is sponsored by Washington GEAR UP and the Common Reading Program, part of the Office of Undergraduate Education. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Jake Leachman on “The HOW of a Hydrogen Organized Washington (and World!)
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Jake Leachman, the Director of WSU Hydrogen Properties for Energy Research (HYPER) Lab, will talk about the research and development he and teams of undergraduates are doing to envision hydrogen as a practical and sustainable energy source. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Visiting Writer Rachel Morgan (Guest of WSU Dept. of English)
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Poet Rachel Morgan is a writer who questions how we make sense of the world in an era when information is exponentially created and chronicled. A graduate of the Iowa Writers’ Workshop, she teaches at the University of Northern Iowa and is the poetry editor for the North American Review.  Her poetry has been published widely in journals and is included in the anthology Fracture: Essays Poems, and Stories on Fracking in America.  Her visit is sponsored by Visiting Writers Program of the WSU Department of English. Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Authors of Soonish, Kelly and Zach Weinersmith, present the 2018-19 Common Reading Invited Lecture
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded:
Held in the CUB Senior Ballroom

"How Little We Know: Why Most of Our Opinions Are Probably Wrong" is the title of the 12th annual Common Reading Invited Lecture, presented by Kelly and Zach Weinersmith. They are the scientist and cartoonist (respectively) who authored this year's common reading book, Soonish: Ten Emergting Technologies That'll Improve and/or Ruin Everything. The Weinersmith's will share their journey exploring and presenting research that has the power to “improve and/or ruin everything.” Come hear—and see—what led this duo to this project, and what they hope you will take away from it! Following their presentation, they will sign copies of the book. Verification of attendance at this Common Reading event will be available.

item.title: “The Art of Comics," a lecture by visiting writer Mita Mahato
item.dc:creator: emma.epperly
item.content:encoded: Mita Mahato is a cut paper, comics, and collage artist whose work explores loss by engaging the transformative capacities of found and handmade paper. A selection of her poetry comics, collectively titled In Between, was published by Pleiades Press in 2017. Her book 1 was recognized by Cartoonists NW as 2015’s “best comic book,” and her comics art has been exhibited in galleries across the country. Mahato's visit is part of a three-day Material Comix Workshop being sponsored by the Dept. of English; for more on this and on Mahato, see https://english.wsu.edu/visiting-writers/.  Verification of attendance available.

item.title: "Fantasyland" Author Kurt Andersen (Guest of Foley Institute)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Kurt Andersen, author of the bestselling book Fantasyland: How America Went Haywire, will speak about the crumbling border between opinion and fact in America in the age of fake news. The United States has widely divergent opinions from the rest of the world when it comes to issues such as evolution, gun control, and climate change, among many others. Andersen will address how has this happened, and why Americans are so prone to fantastical thinking. Sponsored by the WSU Foley Institute of Public Policy and Public Service, the School of Politics, Philosophy, and Public Affairs, and the departments of History and English. Verification of attendance for the Common Reading will be available.

item.title: Business Technology Symposium (hosted by WSU Carson College of Business)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Every year the WSU Carson College of Business hosts a panel of technology executives from leading businesses to discuss how emerging technologies are transforming business practices—both in creating new opportunities and new challenges.  The 2018 panelists are Kashif Ansari (Vice President, Dell EMC), Megan Bigelow (Portland Women in Tech), Frank Harrill (Director of Security, Schweitzer Engineering), and Cameron Schwarz (Systems Engineering Manager, Dell EMC). For more on these speakers and the symposium, see https://business.wsu.edu/news-events/events/business-technology-symposium/ Verification of attendance for Common Reading available.

item.title: "Marching in Gucci: Memoirs of a Well-Dressed Black AIDS Activist" (MOA performance)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Held at the Schnitzer Museum of Art's Pavilion Gallery

Part of reaching one’s own soonish goals is being true to who you are. This multi-media solo performance by award-winning Chad Goller-Sojourner, a Seattle-based writer and storyteller, recognizes and honors October 11 as National Coming Out Day (and its 30th anniversary).  This multimedia oral history performance, set in New York City during the height of the AIDS Crisis around the 1980s, explores the paradoxical and precarious relationship between fighting AIDS while engaging in self-harming behaviors. Goller-Sojourner is a recipient of a distinguished Washington State Arts Commission Performing Arts Fellowship. The exhibition is sponsored by the John Matthews Friel Memorial Arts Lectureship, and the members of the Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art WSU.  Verification of attendance for the Common Reading are available.

item.title: "Quantum Tools to Explore the Universe...and Help Life on Earth" (Distinguished Colloquium for Physics and Astronomy)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Webster 16

Ronald Walsworth, senior physicist at Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, leads an interdisciplinary research group that develops precision measurement tools and applies them to problems in both the physical and life sciences. At this distinguished colloquium for physics and astronomy, Walsworth will describe some of the applications from his lab, from searching for Earth-like planets to solving such down-to-Earth problems as health, security, and navigation. This national leader will help you understand our soonish universe! Verification of attendance for the Common Reading available.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Distinguished Colloquium: Physics & Astronomy – Ronald Walsworth

item.title: "The Transforming Power of Research" (Common Reading event)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Held in CUE 203

Chris Keane, WSU vice president of research and professor of physics, will share his research journey that includes working at universities and national laboratories in the field of nuclear security. He will also discuss his passion for the research happening across all fields at WSU, and the current and soonish applications of such research to the world. Verification of attendance of Common Reading event available.

item.title: "Organic Electronics--Printable, Flexible, Biocompatible" (Common Reading event)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Held in CUE 203

Brian Collins, award-winning assistant professor of physics, will talk about his research developing organic electronics. His research lab--composed of undergraduates and graduate students--is highly interdisciplinary, straddling physics, materials science, electrical engineering, and chemistry. Their cutting-edge research could help improve the design and performance of organic polymers: flexible, stretchable, biocompatible electronic materials that could be used to make everything from printable solar cells to brain implants that restore movement to paralyzed limbs.  Verification of attendance at a Common Reading event available.

item.title: "Resilience: The Biology of Stress and the Science of Hope" (documentary film)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented in Todd 276*

This 2016 documentary chronicles new medical research on the effects of childhood trauma, revealing how toxic stress can trigger hormones that wreak havoc on the brains and bodies of children, putting them at a greater risk for disease, homelessness, prison time, and early death. The film also chronicles the work of trailblazers in pediatrics, education, and social welfare who are using cutting-edge science and field-tested therapies to protect children from the insidious effects of toxic stress. Film screenings will be followed by a facilitated discussion. Common Reading credit is available for those who are present for both the film and discussion.  Sponsored by the Division of Student Affairs, WSU Athletics, Student-Athlete Advisory Committee, Prevention Science Graduate Student Organization, ASWSU, and GPSA.

*Film will be shown also from 5:30-7:30 p.m. in CUE 203.

item.title: "Resilience: The Biology of Stress and the Science of Hope" (documentary film)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented in CUE 203*

This 2016 documentary chronicles new medical research on the effects of childhood trauma, revealing how toxic stress can trigger hormones that wreak havoc on the brains and bodies of children, putting them at a greater risk for disease, homelessness, prison time, and early death. The film also chronicles the work of trailblazers in pediatrics, education, and social welfare who are using cutting-edge science and field-tested therapies to protect children from the insidious effects of toxic stress. Film screenings will be followed by a facilitated discussion. Common Reading credit is available for those who are present for both the film and discussion.  Sponsored by the Division of Student Affairs, WSU Athletics, Student-Athlete Advisory Committee, Prevention Science Graduate Student Organization, ASWSU, and GPSA.

*The film will also be shown from 3:30-5:00 p.m. in Todd 276.

item.title: "The Future of Work and Learning," by Victor Saad (hosted by ASCC)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented in Spark G-45

It's no secret that the future of work and education is shifting. Technologies are evolving at breakneck speeds. Society continually expects fresh and powerful new solutions. But what does that mean for you? Victor Saad, founder of the Experience Institute, believes you can prepare to meet change by being a learner and risk-taker. Join the discussion about the power of learning in this ever-changing landscape. Saad's visit is sponsored by the Academic Success and Career Center, the President's Office, the Advisor Learning Program, Entrepreneurial Faculty Ambassadors, and Student Involvement. Verification of attendance for the Common Reading is available.

item.title: DEADLINE for book nominations for next common reading
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
The Common Reading Program announces that nominations for the 2019-20 book WILL CLOSE THIS EVENING. An online form is at https://CommonReading.wsu.edu/Nominations.

“The next book will be the thirteenth in as many years,” said Susan Poch, co-director of the program with Karen Weathermon since 2007. “Thousands of WSU students have gone through the program since it began, and benefitted from classroom discussions and faculty- and guest-expert lectures based on topics raised in each book.

“The common reading helps first-year and other students experience new ideas and create new and academically focused networks with professors and other students. The program is carefully designed to stimulate critical thinking and strengthen forms of communication around a single book.”

Nomination requirements

Faculty and staff nominating books must provide a moderate amount of information. How does the book fit the theme, apply to a broad range of disciplines, and connect readers to, for example, existing university research, civic engagement areas, and global initiatives? How many pages does the book have, is it available in paperback, and is it a realistic read for freshmen? Additional questions are posed in the online form.

For anyone unable to access the online form, the questions are listed on the nominations webpage; view those questions and submit your answers by email to commonreading@wsu.edu,

item.title: "Fear less, do more" (lecture by Michelle Poler)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented in the CUB Junior Ballroom

This presentation will address your own soonish future by changing your perception of fear and inspiring you to take action. Michelle Poler's humorous and inspiring speaking style has been captivating audiences across the globe. Using authentic storytelling, engaging visuals, and drawing from her "100 Days Without Fear" project, Poler shows how to challenge your comfort zone to tap into your full potential. One of her key findings lies in Abraham Maslow’s "Hierarchy of Needs" where she uncovered how needs not only motivate us, but they also limit us. Born and raised in Caracas, Venezuela, Poler is a social entrepreneur, keynote speaker, fear facer, and branding strategist. She is the founder of the "Hello Fears" social movement. Sponsored by the Division of Student Affairs as part of its mental health unit. Verification of attendance for Common Reading credit is available.

item.title: Soonish Film Festival: A Presentation and Contest of Projects from HD 205
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Held in Todd Aud (116)

In Soonish, the authors, Kelly and Zach Weinersmith, explore technologies in 10 emerging fields and give us a glimpse into the amazing world we will have, soonish. This fall semester, HD 205 students were challenged to create innovative solutions to address the tough social issues that we may face soonish, using videos to promote their ideas. Come see the films and and creative ideas of fellow students--and vote for the top presentations (they'll get awards!). Verification of attendance at a Common Reading event will be available.

item.title: Soonish Sustainable City Projects: Displays by SOE 110 students
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented in Ensminger Pavilion

 

Cities are complex systems of energy, food, water, people, and infrastructure. Cities house most of the world's population and are places where many decisions about the environment occur. Many people in cities may live their entire lives without leaving their urban setting, perhaps not even realizing how connected their health and well-being are to the ecosystem outside, and sometimes even within, the urban area. Energy, water, and food quality as well as accessibility vary from city to city, and local and regional environmental conditions can have a large impact on how a city functions and how it plans for future sustainability.

 

Come and see poster presentations by School of the Environment students in SOE 110 that showcase a semester's worth of research, analysis, systems thinking, and planning for solutions for many of the world's mega-cities. It will be a wonder of "soonish" possibilities that may improve and/or ruin everything! Verification of attendance at this Common Reading event will be available.

item.title: Soonish Sustainable City Projects: Displays by SOE 110 students
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented in Ensminger Pavilion

 

Cities are complex systems of energy, food, water, people, and infrastructure. Cities house most of the world's population and are places where many decisions about the environment occur. Many people in cities may live their entire lives without leaving their urban setting, perhaps not even realizing how connected their health and well-being are to the ecosystem outside, and sometimes even within, the urban area. Energy, water, and food quality as well as accessibility vary from city to city, and local and regional environmental conditions can have a large impact on how a city functions and how it plans for future sustainability.

 

Come and see poster presentations by School of the Environment students in SOE 110 that showcase a semester's worth of research, analysis, systems thinking, and planning for solutions for many of the world's mega-cities. It will be a wonder of "soonish" possibilities that may improve and/or ruin everything! Verification of attendance at this Common Reading event will be available.

item.title: "The Value of Self-Care": by Robby Cooper (HD)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded:
Presented in Spark G-45

JUST IN TIME FOR FINALS!  Come hear both about how you can take care of yourself during this stressful part of the semester (and beyond) and about how these techniques are recognized as powerful components of medicine today and soonish!  Robby Cooper (Human Development) will talk about the importance of self-care as an essential component of healthy development and well-being for emerging adults. He will discuss the recent focus on self-care as a “first medicine” by cutting-edge health professionals. This event will be interactive and allow students to personalize and apply the content to their own lives. Verification of attendance at this Common Reading event is available.

item.title: "Academic Integrity" presented by James Lancaster (sponsored by ASWSU)
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: As we look at emerging technologies, it is important to remember that all research—whether by students or internationally recognized researchers—depends upon ethical research practices. James Lancaster, a professor of human development and psychological counseling at Appalachian State University and a former president of the International Center for Academic Integrity, will speak about the importance of maintaining academic integrity throughout one’s collegiate career. He will also share effective strategies to avoid plagiarism. This event is sponsored by ASWSU as part of Honest Academics Week.  Verification of attendance available.

item.title: Martin Luther King Community Celebration; Ibram X. Kendi presentation
item.dc:creator: makhani
item.content:encoded: Each year, the WSU and greater Pullman community gather to honor the legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and to affirm the importance of a diverse and equitable society. This year’s keynote speaker, Ibram X.
